questions.question_text: Which two tagging related items are valid attributes that may be included in payload of an audit log event? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
B&D: 
https://docs.oracle.com/en-us/iaas/Content/Tagging/Tasks/managingtagsandtagnamespaces.htm#Managing_Tags_and_Tag_Namespaces

Managing Tags and Tag Namespaces
Oracle Cloud Infrastructure supports two kinds of tags: free-form tags and defined tags.

questions.question_text:
As a solution architect, you designed the network infrastructure of a three-tier web application on Oracle Cloud Infrastructure (OCI) and the back-end database servers are put in a private subnet. One of your database administrators requests to have private access to OCI object storage service.
How should you fulfill this request?

choices.B: Attach a public IP address to the instances in the private subnet, and then add a new route rule to the private subnet route table to route default traffic to the internet gateway.
choices.D: Create a service gateway, add a new route rule to the private subnet route table that uses object storage as target type.
choices.C: Create a dynamic routing gateway (DRG) and attach it to your virtual cloud network (VCN). Add a default route rule to the private subnets route table and set the target as DRG.
choices.A: Add a new route rule to the private subnet route table to route default traffic to the internet gateway.

choices.D: Modify the route table associated with the VCN subnet in which the instance resides. Add a following route to the route table: Destination CIDR: 0.0.0.0/0 Target: Internet Gateway (IGW)
choices.A: Modify the security list associated with the VCN subnet in which the instance resides. Add a stateful egress rule to allow ICMP traffic in addition to the port 22.
choices.C: Modify the route table associated with the VCN subnet in which the instance resides. Add a following route to the route table: Destination CIDR: 0.0.0.0/0 Target: Dynamic Routing Gateway (DRG)
choices.B: Modify the route table associated with the VCN subnet in which the instance resides. Add a following route to the route table: Destination CIDR: 0.0.0.0/0 Target: Service Gateway (SGW)

discussion.content:
D is the right answer.
By default a route tables comes with no predefined rules, so we would need to set up a rule for the default traffic to leave the VCN via the IG.
A. is wrong because the security list already comes with a default rule to accept connections on port 22 (egress rule) from any destination.
https://docs.cloud.oracle.com/en-us/iaas/Content/Network/Concepts/securitylists.htm

comments.content: sorry the security list comes with predefined ingress rule, not egress, so no further modification is necessary.

discussion.content:
D is the correct answer. 
A is wrong for 2 main reasons, one you don't need to add egress rules for SSH (port 22) it's enabled by default, two ssh uses tcp not Icmp. 
B,C are not used for internet communication.

D is the correct answer.
A Is incorrect as Port 22 is TCP Port, not ICMP

comments.content: nevermind, i read it again, you are correct
port 22 is SSH, the case does not mention ICMP

discussion.content: Question don't says customer connection source, then, D is correct. If customer is connected by FastConnect or VPN, then, C will be correct.

questions.question_text:
A customer launched a compute instance in the Virtual Cloud Network (VCN), which has an internet gateway, a service gateway, a default security lists and a default route table. The customer opened up Port 22 in the security lists attached to the compute instance subnet, however is still unable to connect to compute instances using SSH.
Which action can resolve this issue?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
I agree with given answer

questions.question_text:
Your customer is using an Oracle Cloud Infrastructure (OCI) compartment named Production that hosts several resources such as compute instances, DB
Systems and File Systems. Each resource in the Production compartment is tagged.
The customer's security team wants to restrict access to DB Systems to only the authorized group of DBAs.
Which OCI Tagging capability can be used to meet this requirement?

discussion.content:
BD is the correct answer.

The Oracle Cloud Infrastructure Block Volume service lets you expand the size of block volumes and boot volumes. You have several options to increase the size of your volumes:
 Expand an existing volume in place with online resizing. 
 Restore from a volume backup to a larger volume. 
 Clone an existing volume to a new, larger volume. 
 Expand an existing volume in place with offline resizing.
https://docs.cloud.oracle.com/en-us/iaas/Content/Block/Tasks/resizingavolume.htm
C is not correct, it's too ambiguous and would not be an Oracle recommended best practice for storing the log files.

Any log files age over 15 days shouldn't be on boot volume but still must be retained for at least 60 days.
So C,D are the correct choices

BD is correct. 
The Oracle Cloud Infrastructure Block Volume service lets you expand the size of block volumes and boot volumes. You have several options to increase the size of your volumes

I take back my answer, I agree with the give answer C,D. 
Block volumes are persistent and remain even after let's say the instance was deleted. 
They want to retain the logs for 60 days, so it has to be durable and persistent.

comments.content: C is not correct. Copying the files is not helping if you are not creating a script to MOVE files older than 15 days. B is the right one (B & D). There is no statement that you cannot go offline to resize and it says that first 15 days should be in boot volume. Copying is not solving (you need to move)

discussion.content: Alfonso, you cannot expand an existing volume by online resizing, only offline you can do it!

choices.B: Resize the boot volume of the instance.
choices.A: Terminate the instance while preserving the boot volume. Create a new instance from the boot volume and select a DenseIO shape to take advantage of local NVMe storage.
choices.D: Create an object storage bucket and use a script that runs daily to move log files older than 15 days to the bucket.
choices.E: Write a custom script to remove the log files on a daily basis and free up the space on the boot volume.
choices.C: Create and attach a block volume to the compute instance and copy the log files.

questions.question_text:
You have multiple applications installed on a compute instance and these applications generate a large amount of log files. These log files must reside on the boot volume for a minimum of 15 days.
Any log files age over 15 days shouldn't be on boot volume but still must be retained for at least 60 days. The 60-day retention requirement is causing an issue with available disk space.
What are two Oracle recommended methods to retain the log files for 60 days without filling up the boot volume? (Choose two.)
